description: From Middle English waxen, from Old English weaxen, ġeweaxen, from Proto-Germanic *wahsanaz, past participle of Proto-Germanic *wahsijaną (“to wax, grow, increase”), equivalent to wax +‎ -en (past participle ending).

adjectives.description: waxen (comparative more waxen, superlative most waxen)

examples: And they that occupye them been in muche savegarde, and have greate consolacyon, and been the readyer unto all goodnesse, the slower to all evyll: and if they have done anything amysse, anone even by the sight of the bookes, theyr conscvences been admonished, and they waxen sory and ashamed of the facte.

description: From Middle English waxen (“made of wax”), from Old English weaxen (“waxen, made of wax”), equivalent to wax +‎ -en (“made of”).

adjectives.description: waxen (comparative more waxen, superlative most waxen)

entries.meaning: Made of wax; covered with wax.
Having the pale smooth characteristics of wax, waxlike, waxy.
examples: It was hard to imagine that the broken thing had once been new; that those withered, waxen cheeks had been fresh and tinted. That her eyes had long ago glinted with laughter.

entries.meaning: (rare) Easily effaced, as if written in wax.
